title: How to Make a Holder for an Electric Drill

parts.name: Turning the Container into a Drill Holder

steps.headline: Mark a slanted line near the bottom of the handle and across to the handle's top but on the opposite side of the bottle (see image).
steps.description: Cover this line with painter's tape. The barely visible seams that join together the two sides of the container will help you stick the tape symmetrically.

steps.headline: Carefully cut along the line.
steps.description:
Move the cutter with a sawing motion to avoid getting stuck. steps.headline: Get rid of the cap––you can pop it off with a screwdriver, saw it off or wrench it out using a vise.
steps.description: Hold the cap tightly in the vise until it cracks loose. You may have to move the bottle around a little to achieve this. Again, be sure to wear gloves to protect your hands.

steps.headline: Discard the bottom of the container, or alternatively it can be used as a holder for other things.
steps.description: For instance, mount it on a board in the same manner as in Part #3 for the holster below and it can hold the light that often comes with cordless drill/driver sets.

steps.headline: To eliminate sharp edges, run the heat gun along all the cut surfaces until the plastic softens and rounds itself out.
steps.description: This will avoid sliced hands while using the holster/container. DO NOT OVERHEAT as this will melt/warp the holster. Wear gloves to protect your hands while heating and do not touch the plastic until cooled.

steps.headline: Punch or drill a hole at the non-cap end of the bottle, which now finishes just after the end of the handle.
steps.description: Cut or poke a screwdriver/awl through this hole in a central position, making it about 2 to 3cm/1-1.5" down from the new rim of the bottle. See the image for guidance. The drill holder is now completed and all you need to do is attach it somewhere convenient on your workbench. Rotate the screwdriver or awl to get a neat hole.

steps.headline: Drill a hole  in the workbench where you consider it will be convenient to hang the drill holder and  supplement the screw with a washer to avoid tearing.

steps.headline: Attach the drill holder.
steps.description: Use a screw with a washer––the washer will prevent tearing of the plastic when the weight of the drill is added inside. The screw and washer must be sturdy enough to withstand normal use.

steps.headline: Try it out.
steps.description: Use the holder to store the plugged-in drill. When you're finished, unplug and wind the flex around the drill. Done!

text:
Turning the Container into a Drill Holder Mark a slanted line near the bottom of the handle and across to the handle's top but on the opposite side of the bottle (see image). Cover this line with painter's tape. The barely visible seams that join together the two sides of the container will help you stick the tape symmetrically. Carefully cut along the line. Move the cutter with a sawing motion to avoid getting stuck. Wear gloves to protect your hands while cutting and keep a steady hand. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/d\/de\/Make-a-Holder-for-an-Electric-Drill-Step-3Bullet1.jpg\/v4-459px-Make-a-Holder-for-an-Electric-Drill-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/d\/de\/Make-a-Holder-for-an-Electric-Drill-Step-3Bullet1.jpg\/v4-759px-Make-a-Holder-for-an-Electric-Drill-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Get rid of the cap––you can pop it off with a screwdriver, saw it off or wrench it out using a vise. Hold the cap tightly in the vise until it cracks loose. You may have to move the bottle around a little to achieve this. Again, be sure to wear gloves to protect your hands. Discard the bottom of the container, or alternatively it can be used as a holder for other things. For instance, mount it on a board in the same manner as in Part #3 for the holster below and it can hold the light that often comes with cordless drill/driver sets. To eliminate sharp edges, run the heat gun along all the cut surfaces until the plastic softens and rounds itself out. This will avoid sliced hands while using the holster/container. DO NOT OVERHEAT as this will melt/warp the holster. Wear gloves to protect your hands while heating and do not touch the plastic until cooled. Punch or drill a hole at the non-cap end of the bottle, which now finishes just after the end of the handle. Cut or poke a screwdriver/awl through this hole in a central position, making it about 2 to 3cm/1-1.5" down from the new rim of the bottle. See the image for guidance. The drill holder is now completed and all you need to do is attach it somewhere convenient on your workbench. Rotate the screwdriver or awl to get a neat hole. Attaching the Drill Holder to the Workbench Drill a hole in the workbench where you consider it will be convenient to hang the drill holder and supplement the screw with a washer to avoid tearing. You could also drill a hole for the chuck key, if desired. This will keep it handy and secure. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/0\/02\/Make-a-Holder-for-an-Electric-Drill-Step-8Bullet1.jpg\/v4-459px-Make-a-Holder-for-an-Electric-Drill-Step-8Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/0\/02\/Make-a-Holder-for-an-Electric-Drill-Step-8Bullet1.jpg\/v4-759px-Make-a-Holder-for-an-Electric-Drill-Step-8Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Attach the drill holder. Use a screw with a washer––the washer will prevent tearing of the plastic when the weight of the drill is added inside. The screw and washer must be sturdy enough to withstand normal use. Try it out. Use the holder to store the plugged-in drill. When you're finished, unplug and wind the flex around the drill. Done!
